modules.title: Module 1: Python Basics
modules.description: Master the fundamentals: Syntax, Variables, and Data Types.

lessons.title: Syntax & Indentation
lessons.theory: Python uses indentation to indicate a block of code. Where in other programming languages the indentation in code is for readability only, the indentation in Python is very important.
lessons.code:
if 5 > 2:
  print("Five is greater than two!")

quiz.question: What is used to define a block of code in Python?

lessons.title: Variables
lessons.theory: Variables are containers for storing data values. Python has no command for declaring a variable. A variable is created the moment you first assign a value to it.
lessons.code:
x = 5
y = "John"
print(x)
print(y)

quiz.question: How do you create a variable in Python?

lessons.title: Data Types
lessons.theory: Python has the following data types built-in by default: Text Type (str), Numeric Types (int, float, complex), Sequence Types (list, tuple, range), Mapping Type (dict), Set Types (set, frozenset), Boolean Type (bool).
lessons.code:
x = 5
y = "Hello World"
z = 20.5
print(type(x))
print(type(y))
print(type(z))

quiz.question: Which function returns the data type of a variable?

lessons.title: Casting
lessons.theory: There may be times when you want to specify a type on to a variable. This can be done with casting. Python is an object-orientated language, and as such it uses classes to define data types, including its primitive types.
lessons.code:
x = int(1)
y = int(2.8)
z = int("3")
print(x)
print(y)
print(z)

quiz.question: What will be the value of int(2.8)?

project.title: Variable Swap
project.description: Create two variables, assign values, and swap them.

modules.title: Module 2: Operators & Logic
modules.description: Perform operations and control program flow.

lessons.title: Operators
lessons.theory: Operators are used to perform operations on variables and values. Python divides the operators in the following groups: Arithmetic, Assignment, Comparison, Logical, Identity, Membership, Bitwise.
lessons.code:
print(10 + 5)
print(10 > 5)
print(True and False)

quiz.question: Which operator is used for exponentiation?

lessons.title: If...Else
lessons.theory: Python supports the usual logical conditions from mathematics. These conditions can be used in several ways, most commonly in 'if statements' and loops.

quiz.question: Which keyword is used for 'else if' in Python?

lessons.title: While Loops
lessons.theory: With the while loop we can execute a set of statements as long as a condition is true.
lessons.code:
i = 1
while i < 6:
  print(i)
  i += 1

quiz.question: How do you stop a loop even if the while condition is true?

lessons.title: For Loops
lessons.theory: A for loop is used for iterating over a sequence (that is either a list, a tuple, a dictionary, a set, or a string).

quiz.question: Which function returns a sequence of numbers?

project.title: Guess the Number
project.description: Write a program that loops until the user guesses a secret number (simulated with a variable).

lessons.title: Lists
lessons.theory: Lists are used to store multiple items in a single variable. Lists are one of 4 built-in data types in Python used to store collections of data. Lists are created using square brackets.
lessons.code:
thislist = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]
print(thislist)
thislist.append("orange")
print(thislist)

quiz.question: Are lists mutable (changeable)?

lessons.title: Tuples
lessons.theory: A tuple is a collection which is ordered and unchangeable. Tuples are written with round brackets.
lessons.code:
thistuple = ("apple", "banana", "cherry")
print(thistuple)

quiz.question: Which brackets define a tuple?

lessons.title: Sets
lessons.theory: A set is a collection which is unordered, unchangeable*, and unindexed. Sets are written with curly brackets. *Note: Set items are unchangeable, but you can remove items and add new items.
lessons.code:
thisset = {"apple", "banana", "cherry"}
print(thisset)

quiz.question: Do sets allow duplicate values?

lessons.title: Dictionaries
lessons.theory: Dictionaries are used to store data values in key:value pairs. A dictionary is a collection which is ordered*, changeable and do not allow duplicates.

quiz.question: How do you access a value in a dictionary?

project.title: Contact Book
project.description: Create a dictionary to store names and phone numbers, and print a specific contact.

lessons.title: Defining Functions
lessons.theory: A function is a block of code which only runs when it is called. You can pass data, known as parameters, into a function. A function can return data as a result.
lessons.code:
def my_function(fname):
  print(fname + " Refsnes")

my_function("Emil")
my_function("Tobias")
my_function("Linus")

quiz.question: Which keyword is used to create a function?

lessons.title: Arguments
lessons.theory: Information can be passed into functions as arguments. Arguments are specified after the function name, inside the parentheses. You can add as many arguments as you want, just separate them with a comma.

quiz.question: How many arguments does this function expect: def my_function(fname, lname)?

lessons.title: Lambda
lessons.theory: A lambda function is a small anonymous function. A lambda function can take any number of arguments, but can only have one expression.
lessons.code:
x = lambda a : a + 10
print(x(5))

quiz.question: What is a lambda function?

project.title: Calculator Function
project.description: Create functions for add, subtract, multiply, and divide, and call them based on user input.

lessons.title: File Handling
lessons.theory: The key function for working with files in Python is the open() function. The open() function takes two parameters; filename, and mode.
lessons.code:
f = open("demofile.txt", "w")
f.write("Now the file has more content!")
f.close()

#open and read the file after the appending:
f = open("demofile.txt", "r")
print(f.read())

quiz.question: Which mode opens a file for writing?

lessons.title: Read Files
lessons.theory: To open the file, use the built-in open() function. The open() function returns a file object, which has a read() method for reading the content of the file.
lessons.code:
f = open("demofile.txt", "r")
print(f.read())

quiz.question: Which method reads the content of a file?

project.title: Log Keeper
project.description: Write a script that appends a timestamp and message to a log file.

lessons.title: Modules
lessons.theory: Consider a module to be the same as a code library. A file containing a set of functions you want to include in your application.
lessons.code:
import platform

x = platform.system()
print(x)

quiz.question: Which keyword is used to import a module?

lessons.title: Dates
lessons.theory: A date in Python is not a data type of its own, but we can import a module named datetime to work with dates as date objects.
lessons.code:
import datetime

x = datetime.datetime.now()
print(x)

quiz.question: Which module is used for dates?

lessons.title: JSON
lessons.theory: JSON is a syntax for storing and exchanging data. Python has a built-in package called json, which can be used to work with JSON data.
lessons.code:
import json

# some JSON:
x =  '{ "name":"John", "age":30, "city":"New York"}'

# parse x:
y = json.loads(x)

# the result is a Python dictionary:
print(y["age"])

quiz.question: Which method parses a JSON string into a Python dictionary?

project.title: System Info
project.description: Use the platform module to print system information and the datetime module to print the current time.

modules.title: Module 7: Object-Oriented Programming
modules.description: Learn about classes, objects, and inheritance.

lessons.title: Classes and Objects
lessons.theory: Python is an object oriented programming language. Almost everything in Python is an object, with its properties and methods. A Class is like an object constructor, or a 'blueprint' for creating objects.
lessons.code:
class MyClass:
  x = 5

p1 = MyClass()
print(p1.x)

quiz.question: What is a class often called?

lessons.title: The __init__() Function
lessons.theory: All classes have a function called __init__(), which is always executed when the class is being initiated. Use the __init__() function to assign values to object properties, or other operations that are necessary to do when the object is being created.
lessons.code:
class Person:
  def __init__(self, name, age):
    self.name = name
    self.age = age

p1 = Person("John", 36)

print(p1.name)
print(p1.age)

quiz.question: What is the purpose of the __init__() function?

lessons.title: Inheritance
lessons.theory: Inheritance allows us to define a class that inherits all the methods and properties from another class. Parent class is the class being inherited from, also called base class. Child class is the class that inherits from another class, also called derived class.

quiz.question: Which class inherits from the other?

lessons.title: Iterators
lessons.theory: An iterator is an object that contains a countable number of values. An iterator is an object that can be iterated upon, meaning that you can traverse through all the values. Technically, in Python, an iterator is an object which implements the iterator protocol, which consist of the methods __iter__() and __next__().
lessons.code:
mytuple = ("apple", "banana", "cherry")
myit = iter(mytuple)

print(next(myit))
print(next(myit))
print(next(myit))

quiz.question: Which method returns the next item in an iterator?

project.title: Vehicle Class
project.description: Create a 'Vehicle' class with properties for brand and model, and a 'Car' subclass that inherits from it.

lessons.title: Try Except
lessons.theory: The 'try' block lets you test a block of code for errors. The 'except' block lets you handle the error.

quiz.question: Which block handles the error?

lessons.title: Finally
lessons.theory: The 'finally' block, if specified, will be executed regardless if the try block raises an error or not.

quiz.question: Does 'finally' run if no error occurs?

project.title: Safe Division
project.description: Create a division function that handles ZeroDivisionError.

modules.title: Module 9: Input & Formatting
modules.description: Interact with users and format strings.

lessons.title: User Input
lessons.theory: Python allows for user input. That means we are able to ask the user for input.
lessons.code:
username = input("Enter username:")
print("Username is: " + username)

quiz.question: Which function gets input from the user?

lessons.title: String Formatting
lessons.theory: F-strings allow you to format selected parts of a string. To specify a string as an f-string, simply put an f in front of the string literal.
lessons.code:
age = 36
txt = f"My name is John, I am {age}"
print(txt)

quiz.question: How do you start an f-string?

project.title: Greeting App
project.description: Ask for the user's name and age, then print a formatted greeting.

lessons.title: RegEx
lessons.theory: A RegEx, or Regular Expression, is a sequence of characters that forms a search pattern.
lessons.code:
import re
txt = "The rain in Spain"
x = re.search("^The.*Spain$", txt)
if x:
  print("YES! We have a match!")
else:
  print("No match")

quiz.question: Which module is used for RegEx in Python?

lessons.title: PIP
lessons.theory: PIP is a package manager for Python packages, or modules if you like.
lessons.code:
# This is a command line example, not python code
# pip install camelcase

quiz.question: What is PIP used for?

project.title: Email Validator
project.description: Use RegEx to check if a string is a valid email address.
